name: A. Buggy Sorting
statement:
Little boy Valera studies an algorithm of sorting an integer array.
After studying the theory, he went on to the practical tasks. As a
result, he wrote a program that sorts an array of integers in the
non-decreasing order. The pseudocode of the program, written by Valera,
is given below. The input of the program gets number and array .loop
integer variable from to loop integer variable from to if , then swap
the values of elements and But Valera could have made a mistake, because
he hasn’t yet fully learned the sorting algorithm. If Valera made a
mistake in his program, you need to give a counter-example that makes
his program work improperly (that is, the example that makes the program
sort the array not in the non-decreasing order). If such example for the
given value of doesn’t exist, print -1.
editorial:
In this problem you should hack the sorting algorithm, of course it was
incorrect. It was correct only for arrays with . In other cases you
could print as a counter-example. To make the sorting right, the second
cycle should be from but not from .
